net.akami.mask.alteration

Interface CalculationAlteration<T>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Comparable<CalculationAlteration>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    CalculationCanceller<T>, IOCalculationModifier<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    CalculationCache, DegreeUnit, GradientUnit, PowExpansionLimit

    public interface CalculationAlteration<T>
extends java.lang.Comparable<CalculationAlteration>
    Definer of the behavior of an expression modifier, in the context of mathematical calculations. Modifiers can change the input string given, change the result calculated or even cancel the calculation. Since the different alterations might have completely different behaviors, no other methods than appliesTo and priorityLevel can be directly implemented from subclasses.
    The two main behavior types provided by the API are the IOCalculationModifier and the CalculationCanceller (both inheriting from this interface), which both define what exactly the modification should be, depending of the input string given.
    CalculationAffections must be handled by an AlterationHandler compatible with the type of alteration managed, determining when exactly in the process of the calculations a modification must be done.
    Because of the priority level feature, a handler must be easily able to sort its alterations from the greater priority to the least. Hence the interface extends Comparable. If you want to sort a list of alterations, do the following : 
    
 List<T> compatibles = someAlterationHandler.compatibleAlterationsFor(input);
 Collections.sort(compatibles);
    Author:
    Antoine Tran
    See Also:
    AlterationHandler

    • Method Detail

      • appliesTo

        boolean appliesTo(T... input)
        Checks a validity between the input given and the behavior of the current alteration.
        The appliesTo method should be called by the handlers in order to determine if the current alteration can be applied to the given input. It avoids unexpected results if the "change nothing" behavior is not implemented by the alteration, and it can check whether a different merge must be returned, in case the affect is a canceller.
        Parameters:
        input - the given input string that will be checked
        Returns:
        whether the given input can be modified or if the calculation can be cancelled

      • priorityLevel

        float priorityLevel()
        Because several affections might want to affect a single input at the same time, the priority level method helps the handler deciding which affect will modify the input / cancel the calculation first.
        For instance, the "let fraction or divide" cancelling affect will have a greater priority level than the cache canceller, because even if the merge of the operation has already been calculated, it is up to the "let fraction or divide" cancelling effect to determine whether this merge is wanted or not.
        A float instead of an integer is used, so that the user is guaranteed to be able to fit as many affections as he wants between others already existing affections. If an integer was being used, only 3 affections could fit between a level 1 priority alteration and a level 5 priority alteration.
        Note that all affections that are both cancellable and input modifiers should logically check for cancelling first.
        Returns:
        the priority of the alteration. Between two different affections, the one with the greatest priority level will take effect first. If two affections of the same type have the same priority level (which should not happen), one will be randomly taking effect first.

      • compareTo

        default int compareTo(CalculationAlteration other)
        Compares the alteration itself with another CalculationAlteration. The compareTo method helps a handler sort its array of affections, so that he gets them from the most priority alteration to the least.
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<CalculationAlteration>
        Parameters:
        other - another alteration to compare to the alteration itself
        Returns:
        a negative number if the current priority is greater that the other's, 0 if both have the same priority, and a positive number if the current priority if less than the other's.
